column2: But he was not to be happy there--nor, perhaps, was he ever again to be really happy anywhere.
column3: But he was not to be happy there-nor, perhaps, was he ever again to be really happy anywhere.

column2: He and his wife were very different in all their tastes and habits, and had never loved each other as well as people should when they marry. Perhaps, after all, it would have been better if in his youth he had married his Dora--the one whom he had pictured in the love-story of David Copperfield and his child-wife.
column3: He and his wife were very different in all their tastes and habits, and had never loved each other as well as people should when they marry. Perhaps, after all, it would have been better if in his youth he had married his Dora-the one whom he had pictured in the love story of David Copperfield and his child wife.

column2: But, however this may be, Dickens and his wife had not lived happily together, and now decided to part, and from that time, though they wrote to each other, he never saw her again.
column3: But, however this may be, Dickens and his wife had not lived happily together, and now decided to part, and from that time, though they wrote to each other, he never saw her again.

column2: It is sad to reflect that he who has painted so beautifully for others the joys and sorrows of perfect love and home, was himself destined to know neither.
column3: It is sad to reflect that he who has painted so beautifully for others the joys and sorrows of perfect love and home, was himself destined to know neither.

column2: The years that followed this separation were years of constant labor for Dickens.
column3: The years that followed this separation were years of constant labor for Dickens.

column2: His restlessness, perhaps also his lack of happiness, drove him to work without rest.
column3: His restlessness, perhaps also his lack of happiness, drove him to work without rest.

column2: He wrote to a friend: "I am quite confident I should rust, break and die if I spared myself.
column3: He wrote to a friend: "I am quite confident I should rust, break and die if I spared myself.

column2: Much better to die doing." The idea of giving public readings from his stories suggested itself to him, and he was soon engaged in preparation.
column3: Much better to die doing." The idea of giving public readings from his stories suggested itself to him, and he was soon engaged in preparation.

column2: I must do _something_, he wrote, "or I shall wear my heart away." That heart his physician had declared out of order, and this effort was destined to wear it away in quite another sense, though for some time Dickens felt no ill effects.
column3: I must do underscore something underscore, he wrote, "or I shall wear my heart away." That heart his physician had declared out of order, and this effort was destined to wear it away in quite another sense, though for some time Dickens felt no ill effects.

column2: He gave readings, not only in England, but also in Scotland and Ireland, and everywhere he met with enormous success.
column3: He gave readings, not only in England, but also in Scotland and Ireland, and everywhere he met with enormous success.

column2: The first series was hardly over, when he was at work on a new story, and this was scarcely completed when he was planning more readings.
column3: The first series was hardly over, when he was at work on a new story, and this was scarcely completed when he was planning more readings.

column2: The strain of several seasons of such work told on his health.
column3: The strain of several seasons of such work told on his health.

column2: A serious illness followed, and afterward he was troubled with an increasing lameness--the first real warning of the end.
column3: A serious illness followed, and afterward he was troubled with an increasing lameness-the first real warning of the end.

column2: In spite of his weakness, he decided on another trip to America, and here, in 1867, he began a series of readings which left him in a far worse condition.
column3: In spite of his weakness, he decided on another trip to America, and here, in eighteen sixty seven, he began a series of readings which left him in a far worse condition.

column2: Often at the close of an evening he would become so faint that he would have to lie down.
column3: Often at the close of an evening he would become so faint that he would have to lie down.

column2: He was unable to sleep and his appetite entirely failed him.
column3: He was unable to sleep and his appetite entirely failed him.

column2: Yet his wonderful determination and energy made him able to complete the task.
column3: Yet his wonderful determination and energy made him able to complete the task.

column2: A great banquet of farewell was given to him in New York and he returned to England bearing the admiration and love of the whole American people.
column3: A great banquet of farewell was given to him in New York and he returned to England bearing the admiration and love of the whole American people.

column2: Before leaving England he had promised to give one other course of readings there, and this promise, after a summer's quiet at home, he attempted to fulfil.
column3: Before leaving England he had promised to give one other course of readings there, and this promise, after a summer's quiet at home, he attempted to fulfil.

column2: But he was too ill.
column3: But he was too ill.

column2: He found himself for the first time in his life feeling, as he said, "giddy, jarred, shaken, faint, uncertain of voice and sight, and tread and touch, and dull of spirit." He was obliged to discontinue the course and to rest.
column3: He found himself for the first time in his life feeling, as he said, "giddy, jarred, shaken, faint, uncertain of voice and sight, and tread and touch, and dull of spirit." He was obliged to discontinue the course and to rest.

column2: This summer of 1869--the last summer of his life--was a contented and even a happy one.
column3: This summer of eighteen sixty nine--the last summer of his life-was a contented and even a happy one.

column2: At home, at first in London, and later in the house on Gad's Hill, surrounded by his children and by the friends he loved best, Dickens lived quietly, working at his last story which his death was to leave for ever unfinished--The _Mystery of Edwin Drood_.
column3: At home, at first in London, and later in the house on Gad's Hill, surrounded by his children and by the friends he loved best, Dickens lived quietly, working at his last story which his death was to leave for ever unfinished-The underscore Mystery of Edwin Drood underscore.

column2: He attempted one more series of readings, and with their close bade farewell for ever to his English audience.
column3: He attempted one more series of readings, and with their close bade farewell for ever to his English audience.

column2: He was seen in public but a few times more--once at the last dinner party he ever attended, to meet the Prince of Wales and the King of the Belgians, and once when the Queen invited him to Buckingham Palace.
column3: He was seen in public but a few times more-once at the last dinner party he ever attended, to meet the Prince of Wales and the King of the Belgians, and once when the Queen invited him to Buckingham Palace.

column2: Soon after, the end came.
column3: Soon after, the end came.

column2: One day as he entered the house at Gad's Hill, he seemed tired and silent.
column3: One day as he entered the house at Gad's Hill, he seemed tired and silent.

column2: As he sat down to dinner all present noticed that he looked very ill.
column3: As he sat down to dinner all present noticed that he looked very ill.

column2: They begged him to lie down.
column3: They begged him to lie down.

column2: Yes, on the ground, he said--these were the last words he ever uttered--and as he spoke he slipped down upon the floor.
column3: Yes, on the ground, he said-these were the last words he ever uttered-and as he spoke he slipped down upon the floor.

column2: He never fully recovered consciousness, and next day, June 9, 1870, Charles Dickens breathed his last.
column3: He never fully recovered consciousness, and next day, june ninth eighteen seventy, Charles Dickens breathed his last.

column2: Five days later he was laid to rest in Westminster Abbey, where are buried so many of the greatest of England's dead.
column3: Five days later he was laid to rest in Westminster Abbey, where are buried so many of the greatest of England's dead.

column2: For days, thousands came to visit the spot, and rich and poor alike looked upon his grave with tears.
column3: For days, thousands came to visit the spot, and rich and poor alike looked upon his grave with tears.
